lesson_1.Title: Asking for the name
lesson_1.Info: When we want to know someone's name, we ask...
lesson_1.Memo: This phrase really means "How are you called?", but is more common than the other phrase we use: "Kako ti je ime?" what literally means "How is your name?"

lesson_2.Title: Introducing yourself
lesson_2.Info: When we want to tell our name, we say ...
lesson_2.Memo: Usually we just say "Ja sam ...", meaning "I am ..."

lesson_3.Title: Being glad
lesson_3.Info: After telling our name we usually say ...
lesson_3.Memo:
This is the phrase we usually add after telling our name. For example:
"Ja sam Ivan, drago mi je!" = "I'm Ivan, nice to meet you",
or more often just:
"Ivan, drago mi je" = "Ivan, nice to meet you".

The phrase actually means "I'm glad!" and to express how really glad you are to meet someone you can use the longer expression:
"Drago mi je što smo se upoznali." = "I'm glad we met each other."

lesson_4.Title: Aking for the whereabouts
lesson_4.Info: To find out where someone comes from, we ask ...
lesson_4.Memo: If asking formally or a group of people, we'd ask "Odakle ste?"

lesson_5.Title: Telling your whereabouts
lesson_5.Info: To tell where we're from, we say..
lesson_5.Memo:
A longer expression could be:
"(Ja) dolazim iz ..." = "I'm coming from ..."

lesson_6.Title: Introducing someone else
lesson_6.Info: To introduce someone who is with us, we say...
lesson_6.Memo:
"Moj prijatelj, moja prijateljica" = "My friend" (male and female)
"Moj momak, moja djevojka" = "My boyfriend, my girlfriend"
"Moj suprug, moja supruga" = "My husband, my wife"
"Moj sin, moja kćer" = "My son, my daughter"
"Moj brat, moja sestra" = "My brother, my sister"

How to pronounce all those words you can find out in the lecture about friends and family.

lesson_7.Title: Titles
lesson_7.Info: For formal situations we use these titles ...
lesson_7.Memo: Letter "đ" is pronounced like "J" in name "Jimmy" or like "g" in word "gym".
